dec: 4 plans across 2 waves: script offloading (W1) + reference packages (W1) then tool permissions (W2) + integration (W2)
reason: Wave 1 plans have zero file overlap and can execute in parallel. Wave 2 plans depend on Wave 1 outputs but not on each other.
alts: 3 plans (merge scripts + packages into one large plan)
5 plans (split integration into protocol update + context update)

dec: 3 new scripts for REQ-04: validate-plan.sh, validate-gates.sh, generate-execution-state.sh
reason: These 3 replace the most token-heavy LLM work: plan structure validation (QA agent), gate artifact checking (execute-protocol inline), and state JSON construction (Step 3 inline). Each is deterministic and needs no LLM reasoning.
alts: validate-summary.sh (already exists)
generate-summary-scaffold.sh (lower token savings, summary content needs LLM)

dec: Reference packages as static TOON files in references/packages/, generated by build-reference-packages.sh
reason: Per-role packages are deterministic extracts from execute-protocol.md. A script can extract the right sections via awk. Static files avoid runtime generation overhead. TOON format matches existing compile-context.sh patterns.
alts: Dynamic extraction at compile-context.sh runtime (slower, redundant work per invocation)
Manual per-role reference files (unmaintainable, drift from source)

dec: Tool permissions resolved at runtime via config+script, not by modifying agent YAML files
reason: Agent YAML files are static plugin assets. Modifying them per-project would break the plugin model. Runtime resolution via resolve-tool-permissions.sh + config/tool-permissions.json preserves static YAMLs while enabling dynamic adaptation.
alts: Generate project-specific agent YAML copies (complex, maintenance burden)
Per-project overrides in .yolo-planning/config.json (mixing concerns)

dec: Hand-author reference packages instead of awk-based extraction (C1, C10)
reason: execute-protocol.md has nested headers, code blocks with # chars, embedded JSON. awk extraction is fragile. references/departments/ already uses hand-authored TOON pattern. Sync-checker BATS test prevents drift from source.
alts: awk extraction with structured delimiters
robust Markdown parser (not bash/jq compatible)

dec: Department-prefixed roles reuse base-role packages (C2)
reason: compile-context.sh already maps fe-dev to BASE_ROLE=dev. 9 base packages cover all 26 agents. No need for 17 additional department-specific packages.
alts: separate fe-dev.toon packages (153 files)
dept-prefix lookup table

dec: Never remove Bash from Dev agents (C3)
reason: TDD RED/GREEN protocol requires Bash for test execution. Restrict non-essential tools only: WebSearch, WebFetch, NotebookEdit per project type.
alts: remove Bash for library projects (breaks TDD)

dec: Soft enforcement for tool permissions via compiled context (C4)
reason: Task tool reads agent YAML frontmatter directly — no runtime injection mechanism. Soft enforcement via 'Do NOT use: {tools}' in compiled context covers 95% of cases. Hard enforcement reserved for EnterPlanMode/ExitPlanMode.
alts: modify YAML at init (breaks plugin model)
pass to Task tool prompt directly (no centralized config)

dec: Token reduction measured by compiled context file size, 25% minimum target (C5)
reason: No LLM token consumption API available. chars/4 approximates tokens. 25% target achievable given packages (1-3KB) replace full @-references (30KB execute-protocol.md).
alts: token counting API (unavailable)
manual measurement (not repeatable)

dec: Fallback: packages absent means full @-reference files used (C7)
reason: Resolves contradiction between backward compatibility and no-full-file rule. 'No full file' applies only when packages/ exists. When absent, full files used as before.
alts: always require packages (breaks backward compat)
always include full files (no savings)

dec: validate-gates.sh uses case-statement lookup table (C8)
reason: 10 steps with different artifacts and skip conditions. Data-driven lookup more maintainable than hardcoded branches. bash 3.2 compatible (no associative arrays).
alts: hardcoded per-step if/then
external JSON config

dec: Wave ordering assumption documented: execute-protocol.md read-only in wave 1 (C12)
reason: validate-gates.sh and hand-authored packages both read execute-protocol.md. Only 03-04 modifies it. Enforcement contract table stays in execute-protocol.md.
alts: move enforcement table to separate file

dec: Corrected T1 plan: library type does NOT remove Bash from Dev — removes WebFetch from Lead only
reason: Original plan T1 said library:{dev:{remove_tools:["Bash"]}} which contradicts Architecture D3 and Critique C3. Dev agents need Bash for TDD. Only non-essential tools (WebSearch, WebFetch, NotebookEdit) are valid remove_tools candidates. Actual agent YAML analysis shows Dev/Senior/Tester never have WebSearch/WebFetch in base tools, so remove_tools only applies to roles that have those tools (architect, lead, scout, critic).
alts: Remove WebSearch from library Dev (Dev doesn't have WebSearch in YAML — no-op)
Add no overrides for library at all (misses opportunity to restrict Lead WebFetch)

dec: resolve-tool-permissions.sh uses BASE_ROLE for config lookup, not full ROLE
reason: Config maps base roles only (dev, not fe-dev). Department-prefixed roles already resolved via compile-context.sh BASE_ROLE mapping (D2). Script reuses same case pattern from compile-context.sh lines 25-30 for consistency.
alts: Map both full role and base role in config (17 extra entries, unmaintainable)
Use ROLE directly and require config to list all 26 agents (defeats D2)

dec: Protected tools guard is runtime enforcement in script, not just config convention
reason: Even if someone edits tool-permissions.json to add Bash in remove_tools, the script silently drops it. Belt-and-suspenders approach: config convention (_protected_tools documentation) + runtime guard in script. Prevents accidental TDD breakage.
alts: Config-only enforcement (fragile, human error)
Hard error on protected tool in config (too strict, blocks legitimate experimentation)

dec: validate-plan.sh uses positional arg not --plan flag
reason: Single-input validator with one file path. Positional is simpler. Architecture C1 says --plan but positional is more natural for standalone validation scripts.
alts: --plan flag per architecture C1 interface

dec: Header-only plan (no task lines) is valid
reason: During step 3, plans may exist with header only before tasks are added. Rejecting header-only plans would break the workflow at planning stage.
alts: Require at least 1 task line

dec: validate-gates.sh uses -s (non-empty) not -f for artifact checks
reason: Empty artifact files should not pass gate checks. A zero-byte critique.jsonl is not valid.
alts: Use -f only (file existence)

dec: generate-execution-state.sh includes --force flag for overwrite safety
reason: Prevents accidental loss of in-progress execution state. Without --force, refuses to overwrite running or complete state.
alts: Always overwrite
Interactive prompt (not possible in non-interactive scripts)

dec: Auto-detect completed steps from existing artifacts in phase dir
reason: When generating state for a phase with existing critique.jsonl and architecture.toon, mark those steps complete. Enables correct resume without manual tracking.
alts: All steps start as pending regardless

dec: Test fixtures created inline per-test via heredocs, not in shared fixtures/
reason: Architecture R4 requires fixtures as part of test task. Inline heredocs make each test self-contained. Follows dept-gate.bats pattern.
alts: Add to tests/fixtures/ directory
Shared setup function

dec: Package @-reference in compiled context instead of cat-embedding package content
reason: compile-context.sh currently uses @-reference pattern for codebase files (e.g. '@.yolo-planning/codebase/PATTERNS.md'). Embedding full package content would consume token budget (1-3KB per role). @-reference keeps compiled context small (~50 chars) and delegates content loading to the Task tool consumer. This preserves existing budget math and pattern consistency.
alts: cat package content into compiled context (blows budget)
Include both @-ref and inline summary (redundant)

dec: get_reference_package() returns 1 on absence with && guard pattern for callers
reason: The && { echo ... } pattern is idiomatic bash and ensures zero output when packages/ is absent. This is cleaner than if/fi blocks in every case statement and consistent with the existing get_dept_conventions() silent-return pattern. D6 backward compatibility is automatically preserved.
alts: if/fi wrapper in each case block (verbose, 12 insertions)
Global flag PACKAGES_AVAILABLE checked once (loses per-role resolution flexibility)

dec: get_tool_restrictions() calls resolve-tool-permissions.sh via CLAUDE_PLUGIN_ROOT fallback
reason: In plugin context, CLAUDE_PLUGIN_ROOT points to the installed plugin. In development/test context, resolve relative to script location via dirname. The ${CLAUDE_PLUGIN_ROOT:-$(dirname...)} pattern is used by other scripts (e.g. resolve-agent-model.sh in execute-protocol.md). Graceful fallback when script absent prevents breakage in pre-phase-3 state.
alts: Hardcode script path (breaks in plugin installs)
Require CLAUDE_PLUGIN_ROOT always set (breaks development/test)

dec: execute-protocol.md changes are additive note blocks, not replacements
reason: Architecture D8 explicitly states execute-protocol.md modifications are additive only. Using blockquote note format (> **Script delegation:**) makes new content visually distinct from existing protocol steps. No existing line numbers shift. Enforcement contract table untouched.
alts: Replace inline checks with script calls (breaks readability for LLM agents)
Add separate section at bottom (loses contextual placement)

dec: Integration tests use skip guards for wave 1 script dependencies
reason: 03-04 depends on 03-01 and 03-03 scripts. During development, those scripts may not exist yet. BATS skip guards ([ -x script ] || skip) allow the test suite to run partially, exercising compile-context.sh tests (T1) while gracefully skipping tests for not-yet-built scripts. This is standard BATS practice for staged development.
alts: Hard-fail on missing scripts (blocks any testing until all deps built)
Separate test suites per dependency (unnecessary fragmentation)

dec: build-reference-packages.sh is a sync-checker, not a generator
reason: Architecture D1 mandates hand-authored packages. Script validates packages contain expected keywords from source files (execute-protocol.md step headers, artifact-formats.md schemas). Outputs JSON {valid,missing,stale} for CI integration. Uses case statement for keyword lookup (bash 3.2 compatible per CN1).
alts: Generator script with awk extraction (fragile, rejected by D1)
No validation script (drift risk R1 unmitigated)

dec: Shared preamble across all 9 packages for commit format, staging, escalation, and verification gate
reason: All agents need identical commit format, staging rules, escalation protocol, and gate templates. Extracting to shared preamble prevents inconsistency. Preamble adds ~200 bytes per file, well within 3KB budget. Pattern follows C6 critique recommendation.
alts: No shared section (risk of inconsistent commit format across agents)
Separate shared-preamble.toon file included by reference (adds include mechanism complexity)

dec: T2 spec is inline prose rather than TOON template literals
reason: JSONL string field cannot contain literal multi-line TOON. Spec describes each file's content structurally so Dev can author the actual TOON files. Dev has full pattern reference in references/departments/backend.toon (36 lines) to follow.
alts: Separate spec document file (adds complexity, breaks plan-is-truth pattern)
Provide exact file contents in spec (impossible within JSON string)

dec: BATS tests split into mock-based (script logic) and real-package (drift detection)
reason: Mock-based tests validate script behavior independently of package content. Real-package tests validate hand-authored packages match expected keywords and size constraints, fulfilling R1 mitigation. Both categories run in single test file for simplicity.
alts: Separate test files for script vs packages (unnecessary fragmentation)
Only mock-based tests (misses drift detection for R1)
